page.title: 18Didcot Power Station.
page.content: Didcot Power Station is a large coal power station. Each of the six cooling towers are larger than St. Pauls Cathedral and the big chimney is larger than the Telecom Tower. Being part of the National Grid the station supplies electricity to the south-western region and the rest of the country. 16-20 train loads of coal arrive at Didcot each day. The coal is burnt to heat water to steam which drives the 4 large turbines which generate the electricity. The steam is then condensed in the cooling towers. Thousands of gallons of water from the River Thames are used every day. The water is put back in the Thames slightly warmer which the fish prefer so this pleases the anglers. The site was landscaped to make it look more acceptable. Some think that the cooling tower shape is pleasing.
